document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 1
content: Table of Contents

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 2
content: Preface

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 3
content: How to use this Volume

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 4
content: JSP 822, Volume 2 sets out Defence Policy on Technology Enhanced Learning in Defence1. The volume contains the majority of Defence Learning and Development policies for Technology Enhanced Learning in Defence; where Defence Learning and Development policy sits outside of Volume 6, it is clearly referenced throughout the volume, and in the Document Information chapter in Volume 1.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 5
content: The volume is made up of Direction and Guidance:

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 6
content: Policy Directives provides the Direction that must be followed in accordance with statute or policy mandated by Defence or on Defence by Central Government.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 7
content: Policy Guidance provides the Guidance and best practice that will assist the user to comply with the Directives.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 8
content: The volume employs ‘must’, ‘should’ and ‘could’ language as follows:

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 9
content: Must: indicates that the policy direction is a legal or key policy requirement and is mandatory.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 10
content: Should: indicates the policy guidance is a recommendation. Although not compulsory, if a decision is made that any part of this policy cannot be complied with, then the Senior Responsible Owner who is ultimately responsible for that decision must thereby own and manage the inherent risks that arises.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 11
content: Could: indicates that the policy is good practice and encouraged.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 12
content: JSP 822 is the authoritative policy that directs and guides Defence people to ensure that Defence Learning (training and education) is appropriate, efficient, effective and, most importantly, safe. Organisations across Defence have their own policy documents which local policy teams populate and manage, based on their interpretation of the policy contained within JSP 822.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 13
content: Users should consult those policies and policy teams, within their organisation prior to JSP 822 and the TSLD Training Policy Team that manages JSP 822.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 14
content: 1 Note that Organisational Learning is captured under the Defence Organisational Learning Structure (DOLS) Framework owned by Joint Warfare in STRATCOM and is not within the scope of JSP 822. The Pan Defence Skills Framework (PDSF) currently sits in Chapter 4 of JSP 755

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 15
content: MOD External stakeholders and contractors accessing internal hyperlinks referenced within JSP 822. JSP 822 is published on  . If the Authority (customer) requires a supplier to have access to additional documentation that is not available on gov.uk, this should be captured within the contract and the onus is with the Authority to ensure that the provider has access to that documentation in accordance with the Information Security policy in JSP 440. If in doubt as to whether documents can be shared with external audiences, the owner of the document must be consulted.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 16
content: Defence Direction for Technology Enhanced Learning (TEL)

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 17
content: Policy Sponsor: TSLD, CDP

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 18
content: Introduction SCOPE

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 19
content: Definition of TEL. TEL is defined as ‘Technology that improves the design and delivery of training in order to enhance learners’ experience’ and is commonly taken to mean ‘Information Technology’.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 20
content: Defence TEL. Defence TEL ranges from Training Management Information Systems (TMIS’) to Virtual Learning Environments (VLEs) to Modelling & Simulation (M&S) Environments3, encompassing a wide range of TEL tools within these broad capabilities. There are currently multiple TEL systems and environments across Defence but the endorsed direction of travel is to ensure common usage of approved, integrated TEL capabilities across as much of Defence as possible, leading to a coherent and connected Defence TEL landscape and a corresponding reduction in the number of TEL systems and environments employed.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 21
content: Defence TEL Role. TEL is a key enabler for Defence Individual & Collective Training. TEL enables the Defence Systems Approach to Training (DSAT) through all elements of Analysis, Design, Delivery and Assurance, with a particular emphasis on enabling the delivery of Defence Learning (Training & Education).

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 22
content: Outcomes. Defence TEL is a key enabler in delivering the Defence Learning Framework (DLF) vision of ‘enabling Joint Operational excellence through high quality learning that maximise the use of all the talent available to Defence’. This in turn delivers the key Defence People Strategy aim of ‘Maximising Talent’ of Defence People in support of delivering Defence Strategic outcomes.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 23
content: 2 As set out in the

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 24
content: 3 Inclusive of gaming, virtual reality (VR), augmented reality (AR) and mixed reality (MR) environments, collectively referred to as XR.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 25
content: Defence Learning Framework (DLF). This provides the overarching Defence Learning Strategy and the context within which TEL must be employed to support Defence. TEL has a key role to play in enabling achievement of all the DLF components. In particular, the development and employment of TEL is critical in realising the ‘Learning Environment’ component: ‘Modern Learning Environments and technologies engage the learner in achieving high quality learning outcomes’.4

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 26
content: Purpose. This JSP 822 TEL Volume principally provides Defence Direction & Guidance on TEL in general and TAFMIS & DLE specifically plus their future replacements through the DLMC Programme. Direction and Guidance on Command-specific TEL is provided by each Command where relevant through appropriate TEL policy documents and Command TEL ‘Hubs’.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 27
content: Defence TEL Knowledge Hub. 5 The 6 on the DLE is a repository for current guidance and information on TEL good practice. This provides a hub for Command TEL Hubs to link into and enables Defence TEL designers, trainers and managers to explore and exploit TEL opportunities in a collaborative manner, improving TEL application and usage across Defence.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 28
content: Defence TEL Primary Systems

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 29
content: Defence TEL TMIS & VLE. TAFMIS is Defence’s current approved TMIS. The DLE is Defence’s current approved VLE. TAFMIS and DLE are currently owned by the DLMC Programme on behalf of Defence and delivered respectively by Army Digital Services (ADS) and the DLE Service Delivery Team (DLE SDT), Digital Foundry, Defence Digital.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 30
content: Use of Defence Primary TEL Systems. The following direction applies to the use of TAFMIS and the DLE pan-Defence:

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 31
content: TAFMIS must be used as the Defence mandated TMIS wherever possible. This will support pan-Defence transition to DLMC replacement services for TAFMIS provision in due course.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 32
content: The DLE7 must be used for all Learning (Training & Education) requiring the use of a VLE to enable the T-DLOD through online and blended learning.8

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 33
content: 4 Prior to disbandment, the DEFAC DTEL Team developed a  in support of the Defence Learning Framework (DLF) – in turn part of the Defence Learning TOM – and a   both can be found for reference on the

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 34
content: 5 The TEL Knowledge Hub is run by SO2 TEL R&D, CEDERA, DEFAC on behalf of Defence.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 35
content: 6 For systems where the link does not work from this document copy this link to the browser: DLE: https:/e

heading: Section 36
content: MODNET: https://modgovuk.sharepoint.com/teams/17799/DTEL/SitePages/Home.aspx

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 37
content: 7 The DLMC Programme has endorsed the use of Moodle as the VLE software for future DLE.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 38
content: 8 Note that an anonymised instance of the DLE, referred to as the Cyber VLE, runs in parallel to the DLE for those Defence personnel requiring anonymised access to learning.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 39
content: Defence TEL M&S. M&S environments & tools are directed by the Defence Modelling & Simulation Office (DMSO) in StratCom and designed in accordance with policy and rules set out in JSP 939.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 40
content: Defence Learning Management Capability (DLMC) Programme

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 41
content: Vision, Intent & Strategic Objectives. The DLMC Programme Mandate sets out the vision, intent and strategic objectives as follows:

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 42
content: Vision: “Defence people, fully enabled by their digital learning and management services, shaping a sustainable workforce and maximising the use of Defence talent in support of Operational Capability”.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 43
content: Intent: Future DLMC services will modernise the services provided by TAFMIS and DLE legacy systems through the delivery of integrated TMIS and VLE digital services.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 44
content: Strategic Objectives: DLMC is to deliver digital learning services through a modernised, flexible, pan-Defence learning management and delivery capability that will:

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 45
content: Provide modern, accessible, engaging and evergreen learning management and delivery services that meet the Defence workforce’s expectations, improve motivation to engage with learning and enhance their learning experiences, enabling our people to plan, access, achieve and record the learning required in support of their personal career goals.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 46
content: Enable a cohesive, effective, resource-efficient Defence Learning (Training & Education) System that meets the learning and professional development needs of the Defence Workforce.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 47
content: Support the delivery of the Defence People Strategy.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 48
content: Provide coherent, timely pan-Defence learning information that enables improved Defence decision-making on workforce planning and structures, workforce exploitation and development, and investment in learning.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 49
content: Enable the Defence Skills Framework by capturing and tracking relevant workforce skills.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 50
content: Enable governance and assurance of Defence Learning (Training and Education), and assurance of compliance with policy frameworks.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 51
content: Resulting in identification and development of workforce skills that enables optimal exploitation of the Defence Workforce to deliver future operational requirements.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 52
content: Responsibilities. DLMC is a programme in the Defence People Portfolio, sponsored by Defence People and delivered by the DLMC Programme Team located in Army Command. Key Responsibilities are:

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 53
content: Functional Sponsor: ACDS People Capability, Defence People Team.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 54
content: Sponsoring Group: People Leadership Team, a 3* chaired Forum with 2* reps from all Commands).

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 55
content: Senior Responsible Officer (SRO): Hd IX, Army DINFO.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 56
content: Programme Board: 1* Forum with reps from all Commands, chaired by SRO.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 57
content: Business Change Managers Forum: OF5 Forum chaired by AH Trg Pol/Assurance TSLD.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 58
content: Lead Users Forum: A desk level forum representing the business requirements of all commands, chaired by SO1 Trg Cap TSLD as the Defence Lead User.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 59
content: Ownership. The DLMC Programme owns and is responsible for the current TAFMIS and DLE services. The Programme Team work in conjunction with a range of stakeholders, in particular the TAFMIS Delivery Team in Army Digital Services (ADS) and the DLE SDT in Digital Foundry, Defence Digital, to deliver TAFMIS and DLE services9. The DLMC Programme is responsible for delivering future DLMC services to replace and/or improve existing TAFMIS and DLE services over the course of the Programme lifetime; transition of future DLMC services to a permanent delivery owner is a key element of the DLMC Programme.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 60
content: DLMC Information & POCs. Information on DLMC progress & relevant POCs can be found on the  on MODNET. There is also a DLMC User Group Network  on the DLE.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 61
content: TEL Procurement

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 62
content: All procurement of TEL across Defence must comply with Government Digital Services (GDS) regulations and follow the TEL Ruleset (see Ch.5), based on the . This will ensure robust analysis of the TEL requirement, minimising duplication of existing TEL and providing sufficient evidence for business cases to be approved by the Cabinet Office or delegated approvals authority. Detailed rules for M&S TEL procurement are set out in JSP 939.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 63
content: 9 Note that an anonymised instance of the DLE, referred to as the Cyber VLE, has been launched and runs in parallel to the DLE for those Defence personnel requiring anonymised access to learning. Ownership nominally resides with the DLMC Programme but funding comes from Defence Cyber.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 64
content: TEL Coherence and Collaboration

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 65
content: DLMC. The DLMC Programme provides a cohering function for Defence TMIS and VLE provision through the design and delivery of future DLMC services. The Programme Team also run a change control process for improvements to existing DLMC (TAFMIS & DLE) services10.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 66
content: Defence TEL (DTEL) Working Group (WG). The DTEL WG (co-ordinated and chaired by SO2 TEL R&D, CEDERA, DEFAC) acts as a Defence hub to share and collaborate on TEL challenges, initiatives and programmes. All TLBs are represented on the DTEL WG. See the  and  .

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 67
content: UK MOD ADL WG. The UK MOD ADL WG is a voluntary WG attended by motivated reps from across Defence to discuss and promote resolution of technical TEL issues across Defence and to engage with NATO ADL initiatives and WGs, including the development of TEL-related STANAGs. See the  for further details.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 68
content: NATO Training Group Advanced Distributed Learning (ADL) Programme. The ADL Programme is a US-led NATO TEL programme developing NATO TEL Policy and Guidance. (Link to Site and Handbook to follow)

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 69
content: DLE Training Support Working Group (Trg Sp WG). The DLE Trg Sp WG provides a forum for the management and review of DLE Training requirement setting, design, delivery and assurance. The DLE TWG (co-ordinated by DCTS) informs and supports the DLE CEB (co-ordinated by DCTS).

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 70
content: The Defence People Function Coherence Group. Led by the Defence People DDaT Team, it provides a cohering mechanism for exchanging knowledge on all Defence HR and Learning/Training Digital initiatives to enable sharing of good practice and collaboration.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 71
content: TACK Model. The Technological, Andragogical and Content Knowledge Model provides a mechanism for cohering TEL requirements and knowledge to support the TLBs and TEL WGs in TEL collaboration & exploitation. The  is available on the TEL Knowledge Hub on the DLE.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 72
content: TEL Integration. TEL Integration at Defence level is driven through the DLMC Programme, the DTEL WG and the UK MOD ADL WG. Commands are responsible for engaging with the Defence TEL Integration mechanisms and developing their own TEL Integration mechanisms as appropriate in line with Defence TEL policy, including the TEL Ruleset (see Ch 5).

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 73
content: 10 TAFMIS and DLE Changes are managed, prioritised, designed, delivered and assured by the TAFMIS Manasgement of Change (MOC) and DLE Service Delivery Team (SDT) respectively with direction from the DLMC CCB as required.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 74
content: TEL Governance and Assurance

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 75
content: Defence TMIS & VLE. Currently TAFMIS and the DLE respectively, these are governed and assured through the DLMC Programme Boards, specifically:

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 76
content: The DLMC Service Delivery Board.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 77
content: The DLMC Programme Working Group.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 78
content: The DLMC Change Control Board.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 79
content: Defence Customer Consultation. The Defence Customer is consulted on TAFMIS and DLE provision through:

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 80
content: The DLMC Programme Board (1*).

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 81
content: The DLMC Business Change Managers Forum (OF5).

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 82
content: The DLMC Lead Users Forum (LUF).

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 83
content: In addition to the DLMC Change Control Board.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 84
content: Defence M&S. Defence M&S is governed and assured through DMSO Boards and Working Groups.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 85
content: Customer Executive Boards (CEBs). As a key enabler (methods and media) to learning (training & education) design and delivery, the use of TEL is to be considered by CEB training governance and assurance functions.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 86
content: Working Groups (WGs). As set out at Section 2.5 Paras 2.5.1 – 2.5.6. and Section

heading: Section 87

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 88
content: Defence Direction for the Defence Learning Environment

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 89
content: Policy Sponsor: TSLD, CDP

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 90
content: DLE Governance

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 91
content: DLE Governance. DLE Governance is set out in JSP 822 Vol 6 Chapter 2 Section 2.6.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 92
content: Roles and Responsibilities

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 93
content: The DLE has a number of roles that require training and additional system permissions. Below is a brief description of each role11. For full role responsibilities see the DLE Knowledge Hub.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 94
content: Defence Administrators. Provide overarching support and guidance on the system, supporting Category Managers to maintain appropriate working practices within their School.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 95
content: Category Managers. Manage the TLB presence on the DLE. Provide governance and responsible for managing and maintaining their TLB structures, including but not limited to ensuring that their environment holds only official information.12

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 96
content: Sub-Category Managers. Manage the Sub-Category presence on the DLE. Provide communication and support of endorsed policy while providing governance for courses within their remit.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 97
content: Course Designers. Design and develop courses on the DLE. Provide advanced course design for learning iterations on the DLE within their remit. All courses delivered on the DLE must be designed by a DLE Course Designer.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 98
content: Course Owners. Own the course content and are the single point of contact for any queries relating to course content and functionality.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 99
content: 11 These role descriptions will be reviewed and updated as required as part of the DLE Training Review currently taking place. Note the additional roles of Learning Plan Supervisor & Viewer will be added in the V7 Update.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 100
content: 12 There is also a Deputy Category Manager role to provide support and cover for the Category Manager.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 101
content: Administrators. Administer courses hosted on the DLE, including but not limited to managing DLE course instances and assigning permissions at course-level.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 102
content: Trainer13. Deliver and support training hosted on the DLE, including but not limited to creating course content. This will also facilitate learner use of the DLE. Sub- categories of the Trainer role are:

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 103
content: Non-Editing Trainers14. Use the DLE to deliver and support training but have no editing rights to change course content.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 104
content: Assessors. Manage, maintain and administer assessments within the DLE ensuring that requirements for aspects such as copyright, plagiarism and security classification are met. Note: it is anticipated that all Trainers will become accredited assessors in due course.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 105
content: Turnitin. A new DLE role has been created specifically to manage plagiarism detection tools (Turnitin) and check assignments. There will be two types of users that will hold the Turnitin DLE role:

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 106
content: Turnitin account manager, responsible for unit management of Turnitin.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 107
content: Trainers or assessors who will create Turnitin assignments and check outcomes.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 108
content: Application of DSAT to DLE Learning Content and Delivery

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 109
content: All learning instances and content hosted on / delivered via the DLE – whether delivered online or as part of a blended learning delivery - must be governed and managed as part of an MTS in accordance with DSAT Direction & Guidance in JSP 822.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 110
content: DLE Quality Rubic

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 111
content: The  is located on the DLE Knowledge Hub. The purpose of the DLE Quality Rubric is to provide an assurance framework for DLE Learning Design & Delivery.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 112
content: 13 Trainers must complete the DLERFT Foundation Module. This is required to be able to use the DLE effectively, updating Cse content when required and building an awareness of DLE capability.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 113
content: 14 This role is required by auditors to complete their tasks.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 114
content: DLE Assurance

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 115
content: Formal training that is delivered online should be subject to formal training quality assurance processes in the same way as any other formal training and education activity. The DLE Quality Rubric should be used as part of the DSAT 1st and 2nd party audit process15 for any course that uses online learning or has identified digital Work Based Training. This will help improve the quality of courses and to identify key areas for improvement. The DLE Quality Rubric involves scoring courses against a range of criteria and any Red scores should form part of a non-compliance task list for each course.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 116
content: It is recommended that an additional Topic is created within each course and that the DLE Quality Rubric and its action plan are stored there, where it is visible to students.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 117
content: DLE Accounts (DLE User)

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 118
content: All Defence personnel and supporting contractors are entitled to access learning available via the DLE.16 Other personnel requiring DLE access include UK MOD recruiting candidates with a training start date, international students, exchange personnel and personnel from other Government departments. To ensure these varied needs can be met whilst also maintaining appropriate security and access controls, three types of account have been created:

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 119
content: Full Account. These accounts can be created by all MOD staff either with a MOD email address or Service Number by logging into  and creating a DLE account.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 120
content: Full Sponsored Account. These are requested from the DLE team using the . This grants full access and rights to the DLE, including self-enrolment onto courses, for a maximum of two years. Accounts of this nature need a sponsor of OF3/C2 or above.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 121
content: Limited Access Student (LAS). These are requested from the DLE team using the . This grants limited (read only) access and no enrolment rights onto courses. Users with this account must be manually enrolled onto courses by the course owners.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 122
content: All queries on DLE accounts should be submitted through the Service Centre 1st Line Helpdesk (DLE) in the first instance.

content: 16 In order to obtain a DLE account, personnel must have a Defence Gateway account.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 125
content: DLE Training

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 126
content: The DLE provides a Virtual Learning Environment (VLE) for the delivery of online and blended learning. To use the DLE effectively, and to gain DLE permissions, DLE Training must be completed.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 127
content: DLE Training is currently constructed as follows:

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 128
content: DLE User Training: A  provided as an optional, self-paced (& self- enrol) online learning course on the DLE.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 129
content: DLE Role Functionality Training (): This provides a learning pathway of five self-paced (& self-enrol) online learning courses tied to DLE roles and permissions which must be completed prior to the related DLE permissions being authorised by Category Managers/Sub-Category Managers permissions on successful completion. The courses and attached permissions are set out in at the table on the  page.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 130
content: DLE Digital Design & Delivery Training: Currently provided through the   (DOLC), a 2 day F2F or virtual online course at/by DCTS, DEFAC to enable acquisition of improved DLE Learning Design skills.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 131
content: DLE Elective Training:

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 132
content: is provided as a self-paced online learning course for those needing to gain permission to use the Turnitin plugin.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 133
content: modules are available on the DLE as optional self-paced (& self-enrol) online learning modules to enhance DLE skills.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 134
content: DLE Content Sharing

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 135
content: All common/reusable DLE content should be stored in Alfresco within the DLE to enable reuse by organisations across Defence and hence prevent repetition and duplication of effort.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 136
content: To enable common/reusable content to be found for re-use, learning designers must tag the learning content by subject using the DTEL Taxonomy.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 137
content: Further details on the use of Alfresco and tagging through use of the DTEL Taxonomy can be found on the  DLE Policy & Guidance Book at  and .

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 138
content: Where appropriate and relevant, DLE content should be made available to NATO Allies. This may require a SCORM version of the DLE content to be created to enable sharing with NATO Allies (as set out in STANAG 2591).

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning

content: DLE Naming Conventions / Learning Catalogue

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning

To help improve the utility of the DLE Search Engine and future implementation of a DLE Learning catalogue, all DLE courses are required to be given (by the Learning Designer) a long and short course name based on the following structure:

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 158
content: Evolving DLE Capability and Function

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 159
content: The DLE is a continually evolving system with increasing capability and a wide variety of potential uses. Further detail on capability developments and guidance on how to use the DLE can be found in the  and in particular the

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 160
content: . The DTEL WG, Command TEL WGs and DLE SDT DLE WGs provide forums in which DLE capabilities and uses can be discussed and expertise shared.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 161
content: Defence Direction for the Training and Financial Management Information System (TAFMIS)

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 162
content: Policy Sponsor: TSLD, CDP

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 163
content: TAFMIS Scope

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 164
content: It is mandated that all organisations provided with TAFMIS are to use TAFMIS to manage the individual training, events, processes and resources of people engaged with Phase 1, Phase 2 and Phase 3 training. 17 This is essential to ensure a consistent approach to DSAT and to provide coherent and complete management information across Defence.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 165
content: All other individual training organisations must instead use JPA OLM for course bookings, the recording of competences and completing training history.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 166
content: TAFMIS directly enables the application of the DSAT process for Defence Training & Education. Details on TAFMIS services can be found in the briefing documents at  and at Section 4.9 below.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 167
content: The course naming conventions laid down in JSP 794 are to be used, where possible, on both TAFMIS and JPA OLM. JPA contains the master list of competences for both systems – new competences cannot be created in TAFMIS. The protocols for change are laid down in JSP 794.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 168
content: Organisations seeking to use TAFMIS as the Defence-mandated TMIS must request access via the change process; see the TAFMIS Portal for details18.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 169
content: 17 For the Army, Phase 1 is termed Basic Training (BT), Phase 2 is termed Initial Trade Training (ITT) and Phase 3 is termed Subsequent Trade Training (STT).

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 170
content: 18 And  ; enter ‘TAFMIS’ in the search box and this will bring up the TAFMIS RFC forms.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 171
content: TAFMIS Governance

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 172
content: TAFMIS Governance. TAFMIS Governance is set out in JSP 822 Vol 6 Chapter 2 Section 2.6

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 173
content: TAFMIS Roles and Responsibilities

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 174
content: Service Delivery. The Army is the Lead Service for TAFMIS delivery. The TAFMIS service is delivered by Army Digital Services (ADS) based in Army HQ, Andover. ADS are responsible for delivering the capability together with its full- service management, including a dedicated helpdesk. Incidents should be raised via the Service Centre which are then passed to the TAFMIS Application Support team to resolve. Change requests should be submitted via the TAFMIS change process19.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 175
content: TAFMIS Managers. All Defence training sites identified for, or supplied with, TAFMIS are to appoint a TAFMIS Manager. The TAFMIS Manager will be the single point of contact for that site and are to follow the ToRs for TAFMIS managers. Initial nomination of and any change to a site’s TAFMIS Manager is to be notified to the appropriate Headquarters. Service Headquarters should advise ARITC of all changes to TAFMIS Managers.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 176
content: Key TAFMIS POCs. These are listed on the .

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 177
content: TAFMIS Access

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 178
content: TAFMIS Infrastructure Requirement. TAFMIS is designed to be accessed from MODNET desktops and laptops across an RLI-connected infrastructure. Where MODNET is not available, RLI-connected infrastructure is needed at the MODNET desktop build standard. Failure to do this may affect the performance of the TAFMIS software.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 179
content: TAFMIS Accounts. TAFMIS Accounts are arranged via TAFMIS Site Managers. TAFMIS users are responsible for managing their accounts through the registration and use of the  tool.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 180
content: TAFMIS Training

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 181
content: TAFMIS Training. Users must be TAFMIS trained to a level appropriate for their role. Users may be granted access to TAFMIS prior to attending TAFMIS training, but they are required to complete the relevant courses within 3 months of

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 182
content: 19 Go to  and enter ‘TAFMIS’ in the search box; the will bring up the TAFMIS RFC forms which should be submitted by the local TAFMIS Manager.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 183
content: appointment. If a user fails to complete training within the prescribed time, their supervising TAFMIS Manager will be notified that system access will be withdrawn from that user until such training is completed successfully. Descriptions, dates and booking procedures for TAFMIS courses can be obtained from TAFMIS Managers. Details on TAFMIS training are available via the .

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 184
content: TAFMIS Continuous Improvement

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 185
content: TAFMIS Change Management. TAFMIS Change Management is authorised through the DLMC Change Control Board and managed by the TAFMIS Management of Change (MoC) Team.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 186
content: TAFMIS COI. Each module within TAFMIS should have a COI to share good practice and develop coherent change requests. These will operate on a mix of SharePoint/MOSS and face-to-face meetings, facilitated by ARITC and supported by the TAFMIS MOC Team.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 187
content: TAFMIS Support

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 188
content: Service Centre. Issues with TAFMIS should be reported to the Service Centre; where required these will be passed to the TAFMIS Helpdesk for resolution.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 189
content: TAFMIS Portal. A range of supporting information for TAFMIS is available via the .

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 190
content: Business Intelligence Service. The Business Intelligence Support Manager is located in HQ ARITC in the Recruiting & Training Intelligence Cell (RTIC). The role exists to exploit the information available from TAFMIS and EMIS. It provides the following services:

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 191
content: Advising on Management Information (MI) and Business Intelligence (BI) as required to support the business.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 192
content: Advising on TAFMIS data structures and data quality issues.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 193
content: Enhancing TAFMIS modules and advising on the implementing of data patches as required to address specific data quality issues.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 194
content: Authorised TAFMIS Change Manager.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 195
content: Advising on business processes associated with data quality issues.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 196
content: TAFMIS Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs). To ensure that the use of TAFMIS (both process and data) is consistent across Defence Training &

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 197
content: Education, all organisations using TAFMIS are to use the TAFMIS Workbooks and Quick Reference Guides for each of the TAFMIS modules. These are available via the .  Further detailed information and instructions on new releases to TAFMIS are also held on the TAFMIS Portal along with relevant service management forms.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 198
content: TAFMIS Assurance

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 199
content: 1st & 2nd Party Audit. Use of TAFMIS in line with TAFMIS Policy, SOPs and direction in TQMs is to be assured and reported on as part of 1st and 2nd Party Audit. Direction on the use of TAFMIS should be laid down in TRA/TDA/TP TQMs as part of the MTS.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 200
content: Integration with other systems. The integration between TAFMIS and other systems means that changes to the implementation or use of one could impact on the others. Consequently, all system changes must be considered carefully and authorised by the appropriate Headquarters and, where necessary, at the Programme level.20

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 201
content: Data quality. The premise of enter data once, use many times works best when accurate data entry is made in the first instance. Data quality is a measure of the condition of data based on factors such as accuracy, completeness, consistency, reliability and time-sensitivity. Increasingly, the use of data analytics to help drive business decisions has emphasised the need to be able to have a single version of a truth to enable successful recruiting and training operations. All TAFMIS users must ensure that data entered into TAFMIS is compliant with data quality standards. To save time, effort and resource, all data entry is to be conducted as soon as practical, with specific attention paid where data is added near to or on month end.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 202
content: Data Changes. Training Providers are to implement a system of validating the data entered into TAFMIS systems and include this in their TQM. When instances of duplicate records, in correct service numbers and records assuming a previous state (e.g. a trainee marked back on site by TAFMIS after being marked off site, or data entered by site, which is then overwritten by TAFMIS) are identified, users are to raise a data change request using the appropriate form on the TAFMIS Portal. Further action may require the submission of a TF and sites are to follow the current guidelines laid down by the TAFMIS Service Manager.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 203
content: Responsibility for data quality. Within each Service’s individual training headquarters, a role is to be nominated to take overall responsibility for TAFMIS data quality. Within each Training Provider, a ‘Data Champion’ is to be appointed with overall responsibility for data quality. Across individual training at all levels, the active monitoring and management of data quality is to take place so that the full

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 204
content: 20 The HQ/Programme must ensure that the systems requiring integration with TAFMIS comply with the recognised learning standards (see Rule 4 TEL Toolset).

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 205
content: benefits of TAFMIS can be realised. Advice and Guidance for all data quality issues can be requested from the ARITC Business Intelligence Support Manager.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 206
content: TAFMIS Modules

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 207
content: Course and Student Administration (CA). Essential management information is gathered by the system from CA users dealing with such areas as Course Administration, Student Administration and Trainee Tracking. These functional areas provide managers with visibility of trainees from recruitment through to assignment to the SCs equipped for operations. Consequently, this module, including the Trainee Tracking function, is to be fully implemented by Training Providers as a first priority.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 208
content: Training Analysis Developer (TAD). TAD supports the DSAT analysis & design process for Training Requirement Authorities (TRAs) and (TDA) Course Design Cells (CDCs). Given the effort involved in migrating to TAD, CDCs who are not already using TAD must liaise with TRAs to prioritise the migration to TAD. TAD will automatically populate fields throughout the course folders, such that as the TRA migrates courses, the CDC will be able to access TAD course documentation. Consequently, all training units not already using TAD are to aim to use TAD in its entirety as soon as possible. It is recognised, however, that the migration of large quantities of legacy information into TAD by Training Development Teams (TDTs) and CDCs new to TAFMIS is challenging. As a result, the TAFMIS Team will be available to assist in the change process where needed.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 209
content: Templates (CME). The Templates module is used to create a graphical model of how elements of the course will be run from start to finish. It allows definition of the number of lessons per day or week, time flow of lessons linked to the course calendar and examination positioning. Resource and trainer requirements and TOs can be added to individual or multiple elements. This provides information on the resources used for training, with a forward projection of resource requirements and, potentially, costs. An important aspect of the Templates module is that it enables the capture of information necessary to improve management of resources, balancing their use to achieve greater efficiency. Templates also provide links into courses to automate InVal. As a minimum, Training Providers are to show each course in sufficient detail to support an accurate assessment of the utilisation of trainers and those key resources with a significant associated cost. The design of courses that call on several different, costly resource types for different lessons/events will need to be prioritised for production in more detail. Data input into the Templates module provides automatic inputs to other modules – for instance, it is essential to identify the ‘test’ elements in course templates in order to allow the Assessment and Validation modules to function.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 210
content: Planning and Scheduling Tools (PST). Training Providers are to use PST. To meet the minimum requirement for use, the current year’s ‘schedule’ must hold a programme of courses with associated start and end dates, as well as associated

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 211
content: key resources. This enables trainee administration, InVal and trainer/resource management to be accomplished using TAFMIS. In addition, skeleton schedules must be created as far into the future as is required to support ‘Trainee Tracking’ assignments and ‘Recruit Allocation Planning’. By fully utilising PST, Training Providers will be able to:

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 212
content: Manage resource shortfalls.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 213
content: Find the best dates for courses based on the course template and availability of resources.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 214
content: Schedule non-course activities.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 215
content: Resource management. The resource management module identifies the requirement for resources that are required to deliver training and is to be used. Training Providers are to use TAFMIS to define those resources that are significant cost drivers or of greatest importance and utility to their own schedulers and resource managers. The Service and Joint individual training HQs are to work together to deliver standardisation of naming of resources to enable balancing and sharing of key resources across Training Groups, Commands and Services where this is sensible.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 216
content: Trainer management. The trainer management module identifies the requirement for trainers that are required to deliver training and Training Providers are to enter trainer details in TAFMIS and use the facility to manage trainers. TAFMIS supports the management of trainers in relation to training and non-training activities.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 217
content: Course assessment. The Course Assessment module provides the functionality to manage question banks, exams and statistics, and to create questionnaires and must be implemented. The scanning software enables the automated input of answer sheets.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 218
content: InVal and ExVal. The TAFMIS module that supports InVal and ExVal is called Course Validation. InVal supports course evaluation during and at the end of courses and is usually carried out by Training Providers. ExVal is the responsibility of the TRAs. Where available to TRAs, they are to use this module. The primary purpose of ExVal is to determine the impact on performance after training activity and, therefore, the validity of the training in preparing individuals for their Role. It measures changes in the behaviour of individuals as a result of a training activity and how well the enhancement of KSA has prepared individuals for their Role. Findings from ExVal may be used by the TRA during TNA in the review of the Role PS.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 219
content: TAFMIS Information Systems & Data

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 220
content: Business Intelligence (BI). At the Headquarters level a BI cell21 is needed to address corporate information needs. The requirement is to gather, collate, analyse and report management information on the performance of the recruiting and training pipeline to provide BI in order to support the commanders’ decision processes. TAFMIS provides two Capabilities for the provision of management information and business intelligence:

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 221
content: Business objects. Business Objects is the reporting software that enables the extraction of day-to-day reports and management information from TAFMIS, which can then be published on SharePoint. Business Objects must be used to prepare all reports on training data within the scope of TAFMIS in order to:

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 222
content: Minimise the need for duplicating and/or re-keying data.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 223
content: Support the Defence intent of establishing ‘one version of training truth’.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 224
content: Reporting protocols and needs will be promulgated by the respective Headquarters, consistent with a common approach across Defence.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 225
content: Enhanced Management Information System (EMIS). The EMIS Data Warehouse is an extension to the TAFMIS Management Information capability across recruiting and training to meet the emerging need for Business Intelligence. EMIS provides stakeholders, through visibility and exploitation of data, with accurate management information to:

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 226
content: management information in an agile manner so that decisions can be made.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 227
content: Enable better informed management reducing the potential for data mismanagement.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 228
content: Increase the effectiveness and, where possible, efficiency of the recruiting and training pipeline.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 229
content: SharePoint. The output of Business Objects reports can be converted into PDF, Word or Excel documents for publication to designated SharePoint sites appropriate to the Customers for the reported information. In this way, the number of Business Objects licences can be kept to a minimum.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 230
content: System interfaces. The TAFMIS module suite is an integrated design intended to support all the principal functions of training design and administration. Data entered into TAFMIS is shared amongst several systems including the Defence Recruiting System (DRS), which is planned to be replaced by the Recruiting

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 231
content: 21 The ARITC Recruiting and Training Information Cell (RTIC) provides this service on behalf of the SRO and all TAFMIS users.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 232
content: Partnering Programme (RPP) recruiting solution and JPA. All of these systems rely on the timely and accurate input of data to ensure the underlying processes work correctly and accurate management information is available. The system interfaces have been developed to support the concept of ‘enter data once, use many times’. This means that some of the data captured throughout recruitment and training is passed to JPA to be recorded on an individual’s record of service, enduring throughout their entire career.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 233
content: Data exchange. Data is exchanged between the TAFMIS modules in a number of ways:

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 234
content: TAD. TAD provides a mechanism for creating, storing, amending and linking the data required for course analysis and design. TAD supports the DSAT process from organising the results of a RA through to developing a full LSpec. At the relevant stages, approvals and authorisations are available to support the exchange of information between TRAs, TDAs and Course Design Cells. Data from TAD is used in Templates.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 235
content: Templates. Templates provide functionality to design a course and define the duration, timing, content, resource and trainer requirements. Data created in Templates is used in Scheduling, Trainer and Resource Management and assessment and validation.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 236
content: CA. CA includes functionality to administer courses and trainees, manage resources, trainers and accommodation and conduct trainee tracking and pipeline management. Data is exchanged between these functions, with DRS, scheduling, CME and JPA.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 237
content: PST. PST supports the process of adding the correct number of courses to a schedule in order to meet the SOTT based on the SOTR for each Training Year (TY), while attempting to schedule courses to satisfying the training requirements within the resources available. Data from PST is exchanged with the CA module.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 238
content: Course assessment. This supports InVal through the use of question banks, exams, statistics and scanning software. Results are displayed in CA modules.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 239
content: Course validation. Provides functionality to Course Design Cells and TDTs to create and scan questionnaires in support of course evaluation and ExVal.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 240
content: Business Objects. This is a management information tool that supports day to day reporting and management information reports.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 241
content: EMIS. This is the corporate business intelligence capability in TAFMIS that extracts a sub-set of the data entered by users of the systems described above and is used to provide coherent management information.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 242
content: FOTIS. This is a spreadsheet-based adjunct to TAFMIS that is used to produce the SOTR.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 243
content: Defence Guidance for the TEL Ruleset

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 244
content: Introduction AIM

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 245
content: The TEL Ruleset describes the principles that are to be used for any development or implementation of TEL.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 246
content: BACKGROUND

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 247
content: TEL is defined as technology used in training to improve the delivery of training in order to enhance learners’ experience. Building on Chief of Defence People’s direction22 , the 12 principles that make up the TEL Ruleset are based on the Government Digital Services (GDS) Technology Code of Practice (TCoP).

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 248
content: LINKED POLICY

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 249
content: Government Digital Services (GDS)  (TCoP) and DE&S Acquisition System Guidance (ASG) as part of the Acquisition Operating Framework. Also: JSP822; JSP440; JSP939.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 250
content: The TEL Ruleset

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 251
content: To facilitate Cabinet Office approval, the 12 principles of the TEL Ruleset must be adhered to23 as part of any business case when developing or procuring TEL for Defence24:

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 252
content: Rule 1. Define user needs25. TEL development26 is to follow a flexible method which allows regular review between all stakeholders (such as managers, developers, sponsors, trainers, trainees etc) and draws on experience and innovation through the . Project leads should understand the needs of the users and wider stakeholder requirements and examine a range of potential solutions to meet these needs. Furthermore, new TEL developments or procurements must clearly show a (documented) effort to meet wider Defence needs as well as TLB or role-specific requirements. Value for Money (VfM), capacity

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 253
content: 22 As per the Foreword to JSP822 (See Volume 1).

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 254
content: 23 Each principle requires articulation on either how it will be met or the limitations that prevent it.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 255
content: 24 The TEL Ruleset does not apply to Simulation. For Simulation refer to the DMaSC Ruleset in JSP939.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 256

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 257
content: 26 Note that TEL development is specific to the development of TEL platforms / tools and is separate of the the development of learning content through the DSAT process that might then be hosted on / delivered through a TEL platform.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 258
content: and capability (including any specific risk mitigation) must always be pre-eminent when delivering a new TEL solution and should be articulated with the perceived benefits of the new TEL solution in the business case.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 259
content: Rule 2. Make things accessible27. New TEL should be accessible for users and by extension, training designers and managers. Consideration should be given to Specific Learning Differences, wider disabilities and Digital Literacy of those using and developing training by means of TEL. Additionally, attention should be made towards the potential training and upskilling of trainers and wider support staff on new TEL.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 260
content: Rule 3. Be open and use open source28. If reuse of extant TEL and associated software is not possible, analysis of available license-free TEL must be evident when considering new TEL requirements. Licence free software such as Open Source (code which can be changed without restrictions) and Freeware, offer the opportunity for cost-effective TEL with no on-going licence fees (some Freeware is only available for personal use); however, due consideration must be given to the security of MOD data and systems.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 261
content: Rule 4. Make use of open standards29. To inform Cabinet Office spend control process, Defence TEL solutions should use open standards to ensure they work and communicate across the Defence Learning Ecosystem with other Defence and external IT systems as required and can easily be upgraded and expanded to meet evolving and future requirements. This includes but is not limited to the standards defined by IEEE and the associated Learning Technology Standards Committee – see Table 1 below30.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 262

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 263

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 264

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 265
content: 30 JSP 939 Defence Modelling & Simulation Policy also provides links to open standards.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 266
content: Table 1: Open Standards

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 267
content: Rule 5. Use Cloud first31. If feasible, under JSP 440 and GDPR guidelines, public cloud should be considered in the first instance as per Government direction. Alternatively, if this is not feasible then sufficient justification to why the procured TEL should or could not use public cloud.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 268
content: Rule 6. Make things secure 32 . Systems and data must be within prescribed Government Security Classification policy and wider Defence Security requirements33. Local unit ITSO and SCIDA points of contact should assist with this analysis for TEL security and associated activities including timelines.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 269
content: Rule 7. Make privacy integral. Adherence to the General Data Protection Regulation should be an integral part of any current or new information system. Assistance through the application of Privacy Impact Assessments as part of the TEL procurement is recommended34.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 270
content: Rule 8. Share and reuse technology35. Existing TEL is to be used if it has been previously procured or designed. Many fully accredited TEL instances have been purchased for MoD use and include the DLE and VLE instances as well as enterprise licenses for authoring tools and 3D simulations such as VBS3. Defence is also required to utilise extant wider Government resources, such as Civil Service Learning products for generic learning requirements and ICS catalogue for commercial hardware, software and services which are common across government.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 271
content: Rule 9. Integrate and adapt technology 36 . New TEL systems should be interoperable with existing technologies, infrastructure and organisation where possible. Good integration enables new technology to work with legacy systems, without limiting the ability to adapt to future demands or upgrade systems.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 278
content: Integration should allow the ability to create, share and adapt learning content and exchange data with other systems and effective planning should identify capability and process gaps. Exceptions to this can only be approved through the Defence Modelling and Simulation Coherence (DMaSC) Rules37.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 279
content: Rule 10. Make better use of data38. Consideration should be given towards the minimalisation of data collection and reuse of data to avoid duplication of datasets and optimise exploitation of information (i.e. within Training Management Information Systems and across such systems) within Government regulations.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 280
content: Rule 11. Define your purchasing strategy39. The purchasing strategy must show consideration towards commercial and technology aspects and contractual limitations. Procurement of new TEL should be justified via the submission of a Business Case with approved means of In-Year funding and, importantly, future sustainment. TEL Project leads should engage with their respective Commercial representative at the earliest opportunity to exploit current contracts and opportunities before exploring bespoke procurement, but noting the following:

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 281
content: Avoid customising off-the-shelf products and services in a way that inhibits their maintenance, upgrade or removal in future.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 282
content: Suppliers must not provide either: systems integration, service integration or service management services, at the same time as providing a component service within that system.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 283
content: Existing enabling agreements ensure that approved suppliers are used who satisfy Government or Defence requirements. These agreements are managed and reviewed to ensure that VfM and quality are maintained. If existing agreements do not meet the TEL requirement then the Acquisition System Guidance (ASG)40 for new contracts is to be followed in conjunction with the TEL Ruleset, which includes the ability for projects to run their own commercial competition under the direction and guidance of an allocated Commercial Officer.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 284
content: Rule 12. Meet the Digital Service Standard for digital services41. If the TEL project or programme includes the creation of a service, then the GDS Standard should be adhered to. This includes the adoption of Agile procurement methods42 and the ownership of code, including intellectual property rights (IPR) should be understood and documented.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 293
content: The contents of this policy supersede all previous MOD Policy on Technology Enhanced Learning.

content: Document Information

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 295
content: Document Versions

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 296
content: MOD will review this Policy in three years, or when changes to legislation or best practice dictates.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 297
content: Applicability

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 298
content: The policy contained in this Volume applies to the Whole Force which encompasses Regular and Reserve personnel43, MOD Civil Servants, and civilians, including the Ministry of Defence Police and contractors. It is noted that training sourced through the pan- Governmental ‘Civil Service Learning / Government Campus’ is not subject to the policies in this document. Any other Civil Service training must be compliant with the policies in this document.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 299
content: The policy in this document does not apply to training deemed ‘Informal’ or ‘On-the-Job’.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 300
content: Organisational Learning is captured under the Defence Organisational Learning Strategy (DOLS) Framework owned by Joint Warfare in UKStratCom and is not within the scope of JSP 822.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 301
content: Diversity and Inclusion

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 302
content: MOD respects and values people of all backgrounds. The Technology Enhanced Learning policy is designed to ensure all employees are treated in a fair, transparent, and consistent manner. All those involved in the management of MOD employees must abide by legislation and should adhere to MOD policy.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 303
content: For more information on diversity and inclusion, please see the   on MODnet.

document: JSP 822 V7.0 Vol 6 V3.0 Technology Enhanced Learning
heading: Section 304
content: This policy has been subject to an Equality Impact Assessment (EA).

content: Defence Training Support Manual 3

content: Designing Individual Training

content: 2023 Edition

document: DTSM 3 Designing Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
