content: Generate variety, stimulation and interest;

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 142
content: Programme different activities intelligently (such as not programming a lecture directly after a session of PT) that build progressively from basic individual Skills lessons through to team and collective training events;

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 143
content: Build in time for movement, administration, rest, meals and breaks;

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 144
content: Consider environmental, seasonal, weather or light factors if required (for outdoor practical and collective training);

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 145
content: Use a standardised programming format that builds routine and publish changes to the norm early;

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 146
content: Simulate, replicate or use realistic or real Conditions;

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 147
content: Have a method of informing trainees and trainers of unavoidable, short notice changes to the programme;

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 148
content: Minimise the administrative or non-training burden to the trainee.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 149
content: Programming is usually carried out by a centralised design cell or Training Provider as a headquarters function. In larger Training Providers it is essential that trainers adhere to the programme as resources will need to be carefully managed to meet the needs of a high number of trainees on different training activities.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 150
content: 10Scheduling Training Delivery

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 151
content: Introduction

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 152
content: 1. Once training activities are programmed the elements should be sequenced, or scheduled, in order that the training is conducted in the correct order to optimise both the acquisition and retention of the KSA. This ensures that training is built up and TOs and their dependent EOs and KLPs are delivered in the order that maintains the integrity of their dependencies (i.e. that the achievement of a TO may require dependent EOs/KLPs to be conducted in a particular sequence in order to ensure that the trainees’ KSA is built up progressively). This, however, may not always be necessary. The course schedule or programme is usually produced by the Course Design Cell as part of the course documentation. Particularly in larger training organisations, it is essential that trainers stick to the planned course schedule, as resources and classrooms will need to be carefully managed to meet the needs of a high number of trainees and different courses. Where there is a need to change the course schedule, this should always be approved by the course manager and trainers should aim to avoid short notice changes wherever possible.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 153
content: 11Piloting of Training Activities

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 154
content: Introduction

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 155
content: To help identify any issues or problems early, a pilot course or pilot collective training event should be conducted. Piloting of a training activity is defined as, 'the first delivery of a newly designed training activity under ‘realistic’ conditions'. The purpose is not only to prove what works, but also to highlight problem areas so they can be revised as necessary. Checking the training activity in this manner will ensure it is cost-effective and, therefore, meets the requirement. The aim of a pilot is to establish how well the following perform when used for real with actual trainees:

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 156
content: programme.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 157
content: documentation.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 158
content: materials.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 159
content: lesson/event plans.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 160
content: location/environment.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 161
content: resourcing, training support and administration.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 162
content: Planning the Pilot

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 163
content: Planning the pilot requires answers to the following questions:

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 164
content: when will the pilot be conducted?

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 165
content: which trainees will be on the pilot?

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 166
content: which trainers will be used?

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 167
content: how much time is required?

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 168
content: are all the resources available and allocated?

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 169
content: what revisions can be made during the pilot? (i.e. what alternatives are available?).

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 170
content: Pilot Stages

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 171
content: Ideally, there should be 3 stages to the pilot:

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 172
content: Stage 1: One-to-One. An initial assessment of the training material should be conducted using 1-3 SME individuals or small teams as ‘guinea pigs’.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 173
content: Stage 2: Small Group. 6-12 people, or medium teams, who are representative of the intended trainee group, undertake the training together. Those conducting the pilot observe closely and frequently gather trainee and trainer opinions by questionnaires and interviews.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 174
content: Stage 3: Field. The first fully staffed ‘production’ course or collective training event, with genuine trainees and all the allocated training resources and administrative support. 100% of the training delivered is monitored.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 175
content: In practice, resources rarely permit the full application of one-to-one and small group trials, and training activities tend to commence with a field trial. Nonetheless, these procedures should be applied to test and revise at least those portions of a training activity which involve high cost Methods & Media and/or where failure to achieve Standards has to be avoided at all costs.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 176
content: During the pilot, it is important to safeguard the interests of the trainees. The trainees should not be disadvantaged because they attended a pilot. The following actions should therefore be considered:

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 177
content: trialling parts or all of the materials before the pilot (e.g. a particular demonstration to ensure it works and how much time it takes).

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 178
content: allocate additional time to the pilot to allow for changes and revisions.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 179
content: adopt intensive InVal procedures during the pilot, so issues are identified early and where possible rectified.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 180
content: ensure that trainees that fail part or the whole of the pilot have the opportunity to be retrained and/or retested.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 181
content: Data Collection

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 182
content: Data collection. A major activity during the pilot will be data collection. A comprehensive system of obtaining feedback is the only way of interpreting what is happening. Table 3 provides suggested information for data collection.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 183
content: Table 4: Data Collection Information

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 184
content: It is important that the methods chosen to collect data can be used to both evaluate and assess the pilot. All data collected has to be analysed to determine what conclusions may be drawn and what implications they may have. The result of this process is a list of realistic recommendations, supported by the data that should be compiled as a report and submitted to the appropriate governance body (such as the CEB) for approval and action. The data collection and analysis for the pilot should consider:

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 185
content: how will the data be analysed (e.g. using statistical methods on test results)?

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 186
content: how often will the data be analysed during the pilot and recommendations provided?

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 187
content: how will the data be presented, (e.g. bar charts, summary tables etc)?

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 188
content: who will be involved in the analysis and final recommendations?

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 189
content: Stakeholder Involvement

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 190
content: Depending on the type of Training Provider there may be up to 7 key stakeholders involved in the pilot:

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 191
content: training management staff.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 192
content: training design staff.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 193
content: InVal staff/cells.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 194
content: trainers.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 195
content: dedicated exam staff (where employed).

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 196
content: trainees.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 197
content: TRA.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 198
content: Each stakeholder has distinct responsibilities, but few are mutually exclusive. The success of the pilot relies heavily on a collaborative approach to achieve all the tasks. Many activities rely on input from more than one stakeholder. Feedback from InVal will result in changes to the training activity during its lifetime. It should be made clear who is responsible for implementing these changes and maintaining the training activity.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 199
content: 12Management of Training Deficiency

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 200
content: Introduction

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 201
content: Managing risks to the trained output (i.e. the KSA of the trainees undergoing individual training) is different from assessing and managing risks associated with the Training System.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 202
content: The responsibility for the management of training deficiency lies with the Training Provider. Where risks or issues resulting from identified training deficiencies cannot be mitigated by the Training Provider such training deficiency-based risks should be elevated for treatment or toleration etc.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 203
content: Identifying and raising training deficiencies shows the stakeholders where training shortfalls exist or where risks have been taken owing to either an inability to train certain TOs (due to weather constraints or equipment casualties, for example) or a training failure that has been picked up through the assurance process. Such deficiencies suggest that trainees may not hold the competences that the training should have delivered. These are essentially unplanned but unavoidable training gaps which should therefore be captured and the appropriate governance body informed so that a decision can be made to treat, tolerate or transfer11 the training deficiency.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 204
content: A Training Deficiency is different from the Residual Training Gap. The Residual Training Gap is agreed by the TRA early on in the DSAT process and is articulated in the RTGS.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 205
content: 11 To the receiving unit.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 206
content: 13Inclusion in Training Delivery

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 207
content: Introduction

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 208
content: Trainee performance is directly related to trainee potential and to any barriers which prevent them from performing effectively. All trainers will be required to work with a mix of trainees who may be affected by one or more of these barriers. Failure to address this can have a significant impact on trainee motivation, performance and retention. Trainers must therefore ensure that everyone has the same opportunity to learn, develop and succeed. That means preventing barriers from arising where possible and helping individuals to deal with barriers when they do arise. This is known as inclusion in training.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 209
content: The DTCF sets out the requirement for learning events to be “aligned with trainee motivation” and for resources to “actively engage the learner” in Competency Group 2. The requirement for trainees to “feel supported and able to relate their learning and development goals” and that their “achievement is used as a motivational tool” is set out in Competency Group 4. All the competencies in Group 2 and Competency 4.1 and 4.2 highlight the importance of considering both group and individual needs when planning, preparing and facilitating learning.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 210
content: Lessons should be planned to provide both support and challenge for trainees, so that all ability levels can achieve progress. Trainers must be able to support trainees in dealing with a range of different barriers to learning, including those linked to welfare, discipline and specific learning needs. Where the barrier is linked to trainee attitude, e.g. confidence, motivation or stress, the trainer will use coaching techniques to assist the trainee in dealing with this.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 211
content: 14Remedial Training

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 212
content: Consideration should be given to developing a remedial training strategy (which would form part of the overall AStrat) that is appropriately programmed and resourced. There is further Direction on Remedial Training in JSP 822, Vol 2, Ch 6, Sect 6.3. Trainees that fail assessments or otherwise do not meet the required standard of performance within the prescribed conditions should be given all available and practical opportunities to be provided with additional, or remedial, training in order to both give the trainee the best possible opportunity to pass the training activity. This will ensure the costs and resources expended on training are not wasted. Re-testing should only be conducted once the trainee has received remedial training to fill the Knowledge, Skill or Attitude gap. Re- testing without remedial training will likely be a waste of resource. A remedial training strategy should consider:

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 213
content: the resources, time and trainer capacity necessary to deliver additional training.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 214
content: the most cost-effective way to deliver additional training (such as integrating remedial training with other or later training activities).

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 215
content: programming in revision and refresher training and conducting regular summative assessments to minimise the chances of failure (‘training in’ rather than ‘selecting out’).

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 216
content: assessment variability (such as question banks) to ensure that trainees do not learn how to pass the test rather than learn the subject.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 217
content: identifying as early as possible trainees that are likely to need additional training (i.e. catching the problem early, where it will take less effort to correct than it would at the final assessment).

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 218
content: use of blended learning methods to provide additional training opportunities.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 219
content: clear policy that explains the conditions under which trainees may expect additional training and where they may not; the policy should also lay out the trainee’s responsibilities for taking charge of achieving their own learning outcomes.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 220
content: Quality in Training Delivery

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 221
content: Training Quality Manual

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 222
content: The Training Quality Manual (TQM) is the CEB-endorsed document that sets the requirements, both in process and output terms, necessary to set and maintain the Defence-mandated QMS. Each TQM will be unique to the specific requirements of the Training System for which it is written. It is recommended that work begins on the TQM as soon as is practical. It is common for the Training Provider and TDA to produce the TQM but the document must also reflect appropriately the activities of the TRA. An aide- mémoire for a TQM is at Table 5, and should include:

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 223
content: Scope of MTS, including the details of, and justification for, any exclusions.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 224
content: Training Quality Policy.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 225
content: Training targets.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 226
content: Quality Records (and their control).

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 227
content: Evaluation Strategy

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 228
content: Training Quality Policy

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 229
content: This should set out the rules regarding the establishment and maintenance of the QMS to ensure that the Training System delivers training that meets Defence mandated training requirements. Therefore the Training Quality Policy should:

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 230
content: be appropriate to the purpose;

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 231
content: include a commitment to comply with requirements and Continuously Improve (CI)12 the effectiveness of the MTS;

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 232
content: ensure that training targets are established and provide a framework for establishing and reviewing them;

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 233
content: 12 Continuous improvement should be embedded in the routine business of delivering training and underpinned by a culture that empowers staff and generates trust so that individuals feel able to step forward with new ideas. In the context of the DTC, the role of the DTM and DTS, in particular, is critical in creating and maintaining this culture of continuous improvement, by promoting the adoption of good practice, the exploitation of learning technologies and the provision of CPD at all levels. That said, all training staff should be made aware of their role in the continuous improvement process.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 234
content: be communicated and understood within the organisation as to the importance of meeting TRA as well as statutory and regulatory requirements;

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 235
content: be regularly reviewed for continuing suitability;

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 236
content: articulate how reviews and evaluations of the MTS will be conducted;

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 237
content: ensure the availability of resources to support the MTS.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 238
content: Training Targets

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 239
content: These ensure that the Training System remains effective, efficient and appropriate to the training need. They should be designed to ensure that the Training System meets the requirements for the trained output. They should also be measurable and consistent with the Training Quality Policy.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 240
content: Quality Records (and their control)

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 241
content: Records should be established and maintained to provide evidence of conformity to requirements and of the effective operation of the MTS. Records should remain legible, readily identifiable and retrievable. A documented procedure should be established to define the controls needed for the identification, storage, protection, retrieval, retention time and disposal of records. In addition, documents required by the MTS will need to be controlled. A documented procedure should therefore be established to define the controls, as required:

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 242
content: to approve documents for adequacy prior to issue.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 243
content: to review and update, as necessary, and re-approve documents.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 244
content: to ensure that the current revision status of documents are identified.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 245
content: to ensure that relevant versions of applicable documents are available at points of use.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 246
content: to ensure that documents remain legible and readily identifiable.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 247
content: to ensure that documents of external origin are identified and their distribution controlled.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 248
content: to prevent the unintended use of obsolete documents and to ensure they are identifiable as obsolete should they need to be retained.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 249
content: procedures established for the MTS, or reference to them (including analysis, design, delivery and assurance of training).

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 250
content: a description of the interaction between the processes of the MTS (such as the DSAT process itself) including the documents needed to ensure the effective planning, operation and control of the Training System processes.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 251
content: Table 5: Aide-mémoire for a TQM

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 252
content: Assessment of Learning

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 253
content: Introduction

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 254
content: Assessment is an essential aspect of any training which must be properly understood and applied. Assessment requires the trainer to determine whether learning has occurred which requires making a judgement on trainee Performance and progress, then to decide whether the trainee is sufficiently competent in a particular Role or Task to be qualified for employment and/or work with or without supervision. The proper conduct of assessment in training can have a major impact on training time and resources, but ultimately will contribute directly to Defence outputs. Trainers should be able to administer assessments in training in a fair, valid and reliable manner, this is achieved through standardisation of conduct and moderation of marking:

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 255
content: Standardisation. Standardisation is achieved by adhering to the direction given in the Assessment Strategy (AStrat), and the detail provided in the Assessment Specification (ASpec) . If an assessment is conducted using the same instructions every time, all trainees should receive exactly the same assessment, regardless of when, where and by whom the assessment is conducted.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 256
content: Moderation. Moderation of marking can also help to ensure that the marking of assessments by different trainers is equitable and fair. In this case, a random sample of marked assessments is marked again by another trainer without first seeing the original score or grades awarded. The resulting scores are then compared to see if they agree. Where scores do not agree, trainers should consult with other trainers, and as a team, identify where the marking system is flawed and adjust scores/grades accordingly. Any problems with the marking criteria should be highlighted to the DTS, DTM or Chain of Command.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 257
content: Although it takes many forms, Assessment serves one of two purposes: formative assessment that allows judgement or measurement of progress towards a goal or summative assessment that judges or measures whether that goal has been reached. Both measures can be norm referenced – making comparison with others (performance orientation) or criterion referenced – making comparison to a standard (mastery orientation). Assessment, then, is the primary measure available to the learner regarding their achievement. It is also the evidence base of that achievement.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 258
content: As with other learning activities the principles of motivation, goal orientation, believability, relevance (both to the operational requirement but also to that stage of development and learning) and trust are applicable. Assessment needs to be sufficiently challenging to be credible and to test deep learning should use higher levels of Blooms Taxonomy. Assessment, to be more than a process that just gathers data, must be

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 259
content: meaningful to the organisation (actually constitute proof of competence) and be meaningful to the learner through a process of feedback.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 260
content: Assessment Strategy

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 261
content: The AStrat is useful as it ensures that the assessments are reliable, valid and administered correctly. An AStrat will give clear direction on:

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 262
content: summative assessment of each TO.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 263
content: formative assessment of trainee progress.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 264
content: how grades should be assigned and interpreted.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 265
content: action to be taken upon trainee failure of a (valid) assessment.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 266
content: a policy for determining pass or failure.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 267
content: a policy for the maintenance of assessment records.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 268
content: Assessment Specification

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 269
content: While the AStrat gives an overview of the training assessment, the detail of how the assessment is to be conducted is contained in the Assessment Specification (ASpec). It contains all the information needed to conduct a valid assessment including the type of test, marking details, pass/fail criteria for the assessment of TOs and the consequences of failure. Trainers should always use an up to date ASpec when planning an assessment. The main purpose of the ASpec is to control what is assessed and how. It is important Trainers assess all of the EOs and KLPs as specified in the ASpec and not make any changes that alter these. The manner in which the assessment is conducted is determined by the ASpec. Designers strive to provide as much realism as possible, sometimes by using simulation, instrumented or scenario-based activities and so unauthorised changes to the realism of a practical assessment may make it invalid. If limited resources make it difficult to deliver the assessment in the recommended way or the ASpec appears too restrictive, the DTS, DTM or Chain of Command should be informed.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 270
content: Assessment of Learning in the Workplace Environment

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 271
content: Whilst the generic guidance on assessment of learning is relevant for all training, there are some special considerations for the workplace training environment. The proper conduct of assessments in the workplace is critical to the assurance of Defence outputs, since it requires making a judgement on trainee performance and progress and to decide on whether they are sufficiently competent in a particular task to be qualified to work without supervision. Trainers should be able to administer assessments in a fair, valid and reliable manner according to the specifications provided. This is particularly important because workplace assessments may not be conducted under the same conditions that would usually be expected in more structured training environment.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 272
content: Workplace assessments are generally practical in nature and are used to test individuals or teams in the achievement of a Skill, or Skills, both mental and physical. They can assess either the product of the Skill or the process involved in employing the Skills and should have an associated checklist to ensure both reliability and objectivity in assessment. The WTS will often require the trainees to be assessed on a Skill that has already been practised and assessed in a simulated environment but which now needs to be confirmed in a live environment. It is important that workplace assessments are conducted in a context that properly reflects the real challenges of the Role. Workplace assessments can be either formative or summative. The detail of what should be assessed and how it should be assessed is contained within the following training documentation:

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 273
content: AStrat

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 274
content: ASpecs.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 275
content: A workbook or other document containing a description of the Performance, Conditions and Standards to be achieved. It is important to ensure that the required Performance is assessed under all the Conditions stipulated (such as, field conditions, without support) and to the Standards specified. This may involve reference to a particular Service manual or handbook which is to be detailed in the training documentation. Any uncertainty as to how the assessment should be conducted and/or recorded should be referred to the DTS, DTM or Chain of Command.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 276
content: Recording Assessment

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 277
content: Recording assessments is an essential activity for all training environments to provide:

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 278
content: A record for each trainee which includes a summary of all test results (both formative and summative), as well as a record of action taken, such as counselling notes or copies of written warnings. This record is then used to guide the trainee’s report.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 279
content: A table consolidating all the summative test results for all trainees. This record, accumulated over several repetitions of a training activity, provides valuable information for InVal of training in general, and evaluation of tests in particular.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 280
content: Supporting information for the assurance (audit, evaluation and inspection) and accreditation of training.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 281
content: Malpractice and Maladministration in Assessment of Learning

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 282
content: Further guidance will appear in the next edition.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 283
content: Training Delivery Roles

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 284
content: Defence Trainer

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 285
content: Defence Trainers inspire, motivate and challenge trainees in order to get the very best from them. To be fully effective, trainers fulfil the Roles of the specialist trainer and that of leader, including: understanding the key attributes of a trainer; effective delivery techniques; the realities of training; coaching; and the use of technology. The DTC will deliver trainers that are fit for purpose and whose training and development are linked to the DTCF. Trainers must, of course, also be fully SQEP in the subject matter they are delivering. If training delivery is outsourced, any trainer requirements must be specified in the contract.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 286
content: Defence Trainers are responsible for the planning, preparation, delivery and assessment of group learning as well as planning and supporting learning with individual trainees. Dependent on your specific work context, this may include the management of trainee attitudes and behaviour, and the administration of trainee records and reports.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 287
content: The Defence Trainer plays a central role in ensuring that trainees succeed in training. You are not only the focus for teaching knowledge and skills, but also for inspiring, encouraging, supporting and challenging your trainees, through strong leadership, role modelling and coaching. You want your trainees to become independent learners, who can continue to regulate their learning throughout their careers. Whatever their ability level, they will need regular feedback and support to help them assess their knowledge and skills, so that they can learn to identify and set their own goals for further professional development.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 288
content: PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 289
content: All training for Defence Trainers is based on the competencies set out in the DTCF. These competencies are graded according to 3 different stages of professional development: Foundation, Practitioner and Advanced Practitioner. On successful completion of Stages 113 and 214 of the Defence Trainer course, you are awarded the JPA competence Defence Trainer Level 1 (Foundation). Completing Stage 315 of the Defence Trainer Course gains you a further JPA competence award of Defence Trainer Level 2 (Practitioner). You then have the opportunity to progress to JPA competence Defence Trainer Level 3 (Advanced Practitioner). This is achieved through a programme of CPD and, where appropriate, additional training.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 290
content: Advanced Practitioner level is awarded by your Chain of Command. In order to achieve Defence Trainer Level 3 (Advanced Practitioner), you will need to work with your DTS to identify ways in which you can provide the appropriate evidence of your advanced knowledge and skills, which should relate directly to the Advanced Practitioner behaviours listed in the DTCF.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 291
content: 13 Defence Trainer Course Stage 1 covers underpinning knowledge and concepts and will normally be delivered through the DLE.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 292
content: 14 Defence Trainer Course Stage 2 focuses on skills development and early application.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 293
content: 15 Defence Trainer Course Stage 3 focuses authentic application and contextualisation in the workplace. It comprises completion of the L3 AET Portfolio and observation of TPs 4, 5, and 6.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 294
content: PERSONNEL EMPLOYED AS DEFENCE TRAINERS

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 295
content: The types of personnel employed as Defence Trainers include:

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 296
content: Military Regulars.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 297
content: Military Reservists16.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 298
content: Civil Servants

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 299
content: Includes all CS involved in delivering and managing training (e.g., DTS)

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 300
content: Specialist Instructional Officers.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 301
content: CS lecturers of all occupational groups, e.g., Burnham Lecturers.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 302
content: Contractors17

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 303
content: Defence Contractors

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 304
content: Lecturer Contractors, e.g., at DefAc, RTS (Halton) and RAFOTA (Cranwell)18.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 305
content: Other Trainers as directed by FLCs, e.g., University Air Squadrons, Officers’ Training Corps.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 306
content: DEFENCE TRAINER ATTRIBUTES

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 307
content: Defence Trainers need to be able to inspire, motivate and challenge trainees, understand their learning needs and expectations, and be able to draw on the right tools and techniques to get the very best from them. To be fully effective, trainers should therefore understand and fulfil both the Roles of the specialist trainer and that of leader, which include:

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 308
content: Role modelling. Through the adoption and promotion of the Service core values, trainers lay the foundations for the behaviours that build team cohesion and underpin operational effectiveness. Role modelling is therefore a core responsibility.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 309
content: Facilitating inclusive learning. Trainers should create an inclusive learning environment where all trainees have the opportunity to learn and reach their full potential. Trainees are trained to function as part of a team, but they also need to be regarded as individuals in order to unlock and maximise their potential. Only by

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 310
content: 16 All types of Reservists including UTCs are in scope less Cadet Instructors.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 311
content: 17 Contractors employed locally in Educations Centres teaching GCSEs and A’ Levels, for example, are not classified as Defence Trainers. Best practice dictates that they should be qualified at one level higher than the subject they are teaching. The local CRA must address Care and Welfare issues relating to their employment.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 312
content: 18 Currently deemed to be working in ‘HE’ not FE. DefAc do DHET and RTS/RAFOTA do Fellowship of the Higher Education Academy within 12 months of taking up employment. This is a condition of the contract of employment. They must undertake CoT.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 313
content: treating them as individuals, based on their talents and knowledge, will they reach higher levels of achievement. Good trainers are able to facilitate learning in the most appropriate way to suit the needs of the trainees. Trainers will need a sound understanding of learning theory and a broad range of skills including the use of modern teaching techniques, learning technologies and coaching.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 314
content: Assessment of learning. Assessment is an essential part of training delivery and trainers are often asked to make critical decisions regarding trainees’ progress through training and subsequent qualification for employment. The proper conduct of assessment has implications for training time, resources and effective capability. Good trainers are able to administer assessments in training in a fair, valid and reliable manner in accordance with the AStrat and ASpecs provided.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 315
content: Care and Welfare. Trainee welfare has a big impact on how successful trainees are in training. Trainers need to create an environment of mutual support and respect where trainees feel safe and know that their contributions are recognised and valued. Commanders have specific responsibilities relating to Care and Welfare; these are detailed in Volume 4 JSP 822.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 316
content: DELIVERING EFFECTIVE TRAINING

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 317
content: The Defence Trainer course provides new trainers with an understanding of how trainees learn and a range of tools and techniques to employ. Trainers should also be aware of the unique nature of the training environment and the codes and boundaries which must be applied to ensure that training remains safe and effective for all.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 318
content: REALITIES OF TRAINING

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 319
content: Trainers will be required to deal with a whole range of issues that might affect the length of time available to teach a lesson (e.g. if trainees finish a previous lesson later than planned). KLPs may need to be covered again if, for example, some trainees have missed a previous lesson/event. In all cases, trainers should understand the following when adapting training delivery to meet the realities of training:

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 320
content: All KLPs should be delivered in accordance with the LSpec. Where it has been necessary to adapt or miss out KLPs, trainers must inform their Defence Training Supervisor (DTS), Defence Training Manager (DTM) or Chain of Command, preferably with suggestions as to how these can be made up at a later date. If the KLPs cannot be delivered, then a deficiency report should be raised.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 321
content: Assessments should be delivered in accordance with the ASpec. If the assessment cannot be delivered in the time available, then the DTS, DTM or Chain of Command should be informed, and the assessment rescheduled for a later date.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 322
content: EVIDENCE-BASED APPROACH

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 323
content: Evidence-based teaching (EBT) has been firmly embedded into the Defence training environment. It has proved to be highly effective in improving direct learning outcomes (achieving TOs) and indirect outcomes (e.g. encouraging independent learning, developing social skills, promoting the desire to learn). Detailed guidance on a range of EBT methods is given to trainers during the Defence Trainer course and is available on the Defence Trainer DLE.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 324
content: COACHING

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 325
content: The purpose of using coaching techniques is to unlock a trainee’s potential in order to improve and maximise performance. It is about helping trainees learn for themselves rather than delivering training to them. Coaching techniques form an integral part of the trainer’s toolbox. Everything should be geared towards ensuring that trainees are successful. Often that simply means responding positively and constructively to their efforts and setting new challenges for them. There will also be times when a more focused individual approach is needed (e.g. to develop a trainee who is struggling, or to motivate a trainee who is finding training too easy). Coaching techniques form the basis of the Defence trainer course, and of learner-centric training, in order to ensure the effectiveness and efficiency of training are maximised.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 326
content: There is no single definition of Mentoring in Defence as the word has different meanings depending on the context. For example, Informal Workplace Training includes mentoring schemes where a trusted colleague shares knowledge and experience over a period of time to assist a new colleague; there are mentoring schemes to assist foreign forces to manage their own security. Each has different aims. Where mentoring is mentioned in this JSP, it is referring primarily to the Role of the Defence Trainer Supervisor (DTS) who acts as a mentor for Trainers. In the DTS context the definition of Mentoring is: ‘where a trusted colleague shares knowledge and experience over a period of time to assist a new colleague’.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 327
content: Trainers should be introduced to the learning technologies available in their unit during the unit induction programme. Trainers should never discount the use of a learning technology because they do not know how to use it, but instead they should watch and learn from other Defence Trainers or ask for training from their DTS and/or chain of command.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 328
content: TRAINING INTERVENTIONS FOR DEFENCE TRAINERS

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 329
content: The DTc is delivered by the Defence College of Training Support (DCTS).

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 332
content: The DTc includes the Advanced Care of Trainees (CoT) course, however, whilst the DTc only needs to be completed once, the Advanced CoT is only valid for 3 years.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 333
content: JSP 822 directs that all personnel in direct/regular contact with Phase 1 and 2 trainees must complete the Advanced CoT course. If you are still in a trainer position after 3 years of completing the Advanced CoT course, or, you have returned to a trainer position after 3 years of completing the Advanced CoT course, you will have to complete the course again. Table 2 has an overview of the Advanced Care of Trainee course.

content: As with the Advanced CoT course, the Basic CoT course is only valid for 3 years.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 336
content: All staff within the Training Establishment MUST complete Basic CoT through the e- learning package on DLE. The Basic CoT course must be completed prior to competing the Advanced CoT course. Table 2 has an overview of the Basic Care of Trainee course.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 340
content: LEGACY DEFENCE TRAINER TRAINING COURSES

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 341
content: JSP 822 states that Defence must recognise those with previous experience and qualifications and provide the necessary up-skilling to refresh and professionalise trainers. Assessment of personnel identified for the delivery or supervision of Defence training is key. It is the responsibility of DTSs or nominated TMS to carry out such assessments and to ensure the completion of any necessary training interventions.

document: DTSM 4 Delivery of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 342
content: Para 16 below contains 3 legacy Defence Train the Trainer courses that were replaced by the DTc. The DTTT V1 and DTTT V2 courses are no longer delivered, whilst DTTT Ph3 is still still delivered, by the Army, however, it is not endorsed by the 1* TSLD Policy and Assurance Group (PAG).

content: Defence recognises that these courses, with the additional training / actions listed, are deemed to be equivalents, and therefore, an acceptable alternatives, to the DTc.

heading: Section 348
content: Defence Trainers holding a recognised external equivalent or higher qualification are to be assessed on arrival in post22 to ensure that they are competent. The DTS or nominated TMS will carry out the assessment. If the individual’s skill set is below the standard required for the type of training they will be delivering, they are to complete the necessary training interventions.
