heading: Section 186
content: Piloting

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 187
content: The aims of piloting are to allow:

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 188
content: The systematic gathering of information to confirm validity of data gathering tools.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 189
content: The identification of technical inaccuracies and faults.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 190
content: Testing the questions. When piloting (testing) the questions these points should be borne in mind:

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 191
content: The question should involve only one idea.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 192
content: The question should be worded as simply as possible in light of the ability of the target group.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 193
content: The question should be as brief as possible.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 194
content: The question should be as direct as possible.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 195
content: The question should allow the respondent to admit lack of knowledge without loss of face.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 196
content: The question should be positively phrased - not looking for negative response.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 197
content: The question should not influence the response.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 198
content: Piloting process. For questionnaires, when the initial construction is complete, in addition to testing the questions, the questionnaire must be piloted as follows:

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 199
content: The questionnaire is completed by an individual under the close supervision and with the assistance of the designer. Any difficulties found or comments made by the person completing it should be noted. The individual chosen should be either a member of the group for whom the questionnaire is intended, or as much like the members of this group as possible. Ideally, this procedure should be carried out a number of times with different people.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 200
content: The questionnaire is amended to solve problems and ambiguities found in the first stage.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 201
content: The amended questionnaire is then completed under the same conditions that will prevail when it is eventually administered. Again, members of the group used should be as near as possible to those for whom the questionnaire is intended. The respondents should be asked for comments or criticisms after they have completed the questionnaire.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 202
content: The questionnaire is amended to eliminate any difficulties or ambiguities remaining. Analysis of the answers given should assist in indicating any inconsistencies in answers that may be the fault of the questionnaire.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 203
content: Outcomes. Only after effective piloting can the questionnaire be considered ready for use. Even then the questionnaire will not be perfect. Answers given and comments made by those completing the questionnaire will indicate, in some cases, that further amendments are required:

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 204
content: If the structure of the design does not need any alteration following the pilot, then information obtained from the pilot can be used as part of the population data. However, where the population is to be analysed by sampling in order to prevent any misrepresentation or confusion, the data-gathering pilot should be conducted on a separate sample of the population.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 205
content: Once the objective(s) of the study has/have clearly been stated, including sample/population size and the quality and type of information to be received (qualitative and quantitative), the process of establishing the data gathering techniques can begin.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 206
content: Sources of information. When conducting a pilot careful consideration should be given as to who would be the best source of information for particular areas:

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 207
content: Subject Matter Experts (SME) and trainers can provide useful feedback in respect of the technical content included in the interview/questionnaire and the language used.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 208
content: Representative operators can be used to review the responses already obtained from SME input. In addition they can also provide information on:

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 209
content: Operator reaction.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 210
content: Ease of completion.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 211
content: Sequence of activities.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 212
content: Time taken to complete questionnaire.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 213
content: Depth of response required.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 214
content: Piloting pre-requisites. There are certain pre-requisites for piloting when carrying out a study:

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 215
content: High cost.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 216
content: Large target population.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 217
content: Complex subject matter.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 218
content: Tasks of a critical nature.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 219
content: Choice of data gathering techniques

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 220
content: Once the objective(s) of the research have been clearly stated, including the sample/population size and the quality and type of information to be received (either qualitative or quantitative data), then the process of establishing the technique to be employed to gather the data can begin. The choice of data gathering technique(s) will depend on the sample size, resource implications and many other factors. In all cases the data gathering method should be fit for purpose and developed by suitably qualified and experienced personnel.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 221
content: Questionnaire. A questionnaire can be used to cover a large number of people at relatively low cost and the data it provides is generally easy to analyse. However, questionnaires are difficult to design, are resource intensive and require piloting and pre- testing to ensure that they are collecting the right types of information. Questionnaires do not always allow great flexibility, may not be completed by the recipient, and response rates are not always as high as the team doing the analysis would wish.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 222
content: Interview. Data can be gathered from Role holders and their employers by interview. While the interview allows the personal touch to be brought to the analysis process, and its inherent flexibility, care needs to be taken to avoid bias. The process is time-consuming and data analysis can be difficult.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 223
content: Observation. Observation of personnel carrying out their tasks can also provide useful information but it is a very labour-intensive means of acquiring data. It is usually limited by the range of tasks being undertaken and can be misleading if the observer is unfamiliar with the task.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 224
content: Document research. When conducting a study it may be necessary to consult documents such as interim reports from on-going related studies, exercise reports, operational reports, current training documentation, doctrine and policy documents and manufacturer’s manuals.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 225
content: A conference of experts. This is sometimes known as a Technical Conference or Focus Group and is held when it is necessary to discuss the nature of the Role with others who are experts in that particular field. In some cases this may be the only data gathering method available or needed. It produces quick results, but the problem with experts is that they tend to overlook routine aspects of a Role that could present problems to the non- expert. This method can also be used to analyse findings (e.g. from questionnaires).

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 226
content: Critical incident technique. The critical incident technique is the procedure for collecting observed incidents that have proven very important or critical to performance. It has been used extensively in civilian flight safety investigations and can be used to provide data on the relevance of training to performance of the Role or task. However, this technique can be very lengthy and labour intensive when used to identify the whole spectrum of tasks that make up a particular Role.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 227
content: Questionnaires

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 228
content: Questionnaires can gather qualitative and quantitative information and are very useful in both InVal and ExVal. Questionnaires sent to ex-trainees sometime after their course can provide useful information about the relevance of training. Questionnaires should be sent out on a routine basis to ex-trainees and their supervisors at an appropriate period on completion of training (normally 6-9 months). This type of questionnaire looks all the tasks conducted, addressing:

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 229
content: Do the operators carry out the tasks for which they were trained?

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 230
content: How well were the operators trained for these tasks?

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 231
content: Do the operators carry out any other tasks for which they were not trained?

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 232
content: Constructing a questionnaire. When producing a questionnaire these points should be borne in mind:

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 233
content: Introduction/rapport. The introduction, or covering letter, to the questionnaire is very important, because unless the full co-operation of the respondent is obtained the results are useless. To ensure willing co-operation, the questionnaire should create and maintain rapport with the respondent. The purpose of the questionnaire should be explained whether in a written introduction or by the

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 234
content: person administering the questionnaire. It should be made clear that respondents’ opinions are valued and could make a difference to the results of the project.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 235
content: Presentation. The questionnaire should look well prepared and be easy to complete.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 236
content: Instructions. Instructions on how to complete the questions should be simple, clear and concise.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 237
content: Language. The language used in questions asking for criticisms should be impersonal and permit the expression of frank replies.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 238
content: Questions. Questions should be:

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 239
content: As short as comprehensive coverage allows and must be relevant to the information required.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 240
content: In a logical sequence. Questions relating to a specific subject should be placed together.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 241
content: Precise and specific. Vague questions will lead to vague responses due to different interpretation. If a group of questions does not apply to everyone it must be made apparent who is to answer them. Filtering of questions is recommended.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 242
content: Capable of being answered. Respondents must be capable of answering the questions and have adequate knowledge/experience to provide meaningful responses.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 243
content: Confidentiality. Respondents must be reassured that the questionnaire will be treated in strict confidence and that completed questionnaires will only be seen by the analysis team and destroyed once analysis is completed.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 244
content: Clarification. Provide a contact name and telephone number for any queries. Include a date for completion and return of the questionnaire.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 245
content: Details. One part of the questionnaire from which the analyst can obtain useful data is the element on personal details. In deciding what personal details are required, the analyst will be guided by the requirement of the analysis. The analyst must ensure that the questionnaire asks for all the details that will provide meaningful data for the analysis, while at the same time not asking for details that are clearly irrelevant to the analysis, as by doing so this may tend to alienate some respondents. If the analyst requires some particular detail, but considers that the respondent may not realise why it is required, the analyst must explain the reason behind asking for the information. Increasing the degree of openness of the potential response received can be achieved by offering anonymity (discussed earlier) by not including clearly attributable details in the personal details. However, if anonymity is quoted it must be honoured. Questions over confidentiality cannot only taint the study but may also negate the chance for further open and honest dialogue.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 246
content: Dangerous questions. There are certain types of questions which should be regarded as ‘dangerous’, producing inaccurate and immeasurable answers, or, at best, vague responses which can easily be misinterpreted:

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 247
content: Multiple questions. These have a variety of responses ‘Yes/Yes’ ‘Yes/No’ ‘No/Yes’ ‘No/No’. For example ‘Are you supervised at work and do you rely on manuals?

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 248
content: Negative questions. These are difficult to understand and it is unclear what the response means. For example to answer ‘No’ to the question ‘Would you prefer not to have to account for this equipment?’ is confusing. Questions are more readily understood if phrased in the positive. For example ‘Do you think you should account for this equipment?’

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 249
content: Leading questions. Beginning the question with words such as ‘It’s obvious that...’ can influence the respondent’s reply. In the closed question format, limiting the fields of response to ‘Very Interesting’ ‘Interesting’ and ‘of some interest’ steers the respondent away from the response ‘Tedious’.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 250
content: Loaded questions. These are similar to leading questions but tend to have an emotional overtone, for example ‘Have you stopped cheating in tests?’ and ‘Which aspects of your training were irrelevant?’

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 251
content: Prestige bias questions. Some questions may tempt the respondents to reply in a way that will present them in the strongest light, hence there might be a reluctance to admit that certain tasks are difficult or never carried out.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 252
content: Anonymous questionnaires. Making the questionnaire anonymous (not adding clearly identifiable details which can be traced) has the advantage of encouraging more candid responses, increasing the degree of openness. However, its main drawback is that it is not possible to analyse the responses further, through follow up interviews. If anonymity is promised it must be honoured. Questions over confidentiality not only taint the study, but also negate the opportunity for further open and objective dialogue.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 253
content: Advantages and disadvantages of questionnaires. When gathering data using written questionnaires analysts must be aware of the respective advantages and disadvantages:

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 254
content: Advantages:

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 255
content: Relatively cheap way of data collection.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 256
content: Large target population.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 257
content: Largely objective although there could be bias in analysis of qualitative responses.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 258
content: Potential to automate data entry and analysis.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 259
content: Can be anonymous.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 260
content: Questions can be asked in a consistent manner.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 261
content: Disadvantages:

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 262
content: No guarantee of respondent identity.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 263
content: Response rate may be low.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 264
content: Impersonal - difficult to establish a rapport with respondent.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 265
content: May be limited by length.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 266
content: Investment needed to develop and pilot the questionnaire.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 267
content: Interviews

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 268
content: Purpose. An interview is not an aimless chat but a method of obtaining specific information. An interviewer must work out beforehand what information is required; otherwise, the interview will be ineffective and a waste of time. The questions should be incorporated into an interview schedule, which will:

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 269
content: Remind the interviewer of the areas that must be covered.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 270
content: Provide a framework for the interview and ensure that data are collected in a systematic and standardised way.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 271
content: Interviews can be structured, semi-structured or unstructured (open ended); this refers to the degree to which the interviewer follows prescribed questions or deviates using prompts to gain further information from the interviewee. Generally, the more structured the interview, the more comparisons can be drawn between responses. However, unstructured interviews can provide richer data and may be useful if the interviewer has only a limited knowledge about the subject matter of the interview.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 272
content: Interviews involve going outside the immediate training organisation to interview employing officers and ex-trainees at all levels in field units. Gaining entry to these units and access to those who are required for interview needs careful planning and proper authority. The question of the appropriate ranks of interviewer and interviewee should also be considered.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 273
content: The interview schedule. The interview schedule can be regarded as a verbal questionnaire but differs from the written questionnaire in that the instructions are for the interviewer not the respondent (interviewee). The instructions should indicate:

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 274
content: The amount/level of background information to be provided.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 275
content: The amount of prompting allowed.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 276
content: The method(s) of recording and interpreting responses.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 277
content: The instructions should assist the interviewer in conducting the interview allowing them to place a mark against one of the responses already included on the sheet. However, there should be sufficient space to record open responses.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 278
content: General techniques of interviewing. An interview is not an interrogation but a relaxed, two way exchange with the interviewer maintaining an open and understanding attitude. The interviewer must not, however, allow the interview to pass from their control. The structure of the interview must be decided beforehand on the basis of the information required. While the interviewer must be flexible and allow the subjects to express themselves, the interviewer must be firm and maintain control.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 279
content: Role of the interviewer. The effective interviewer listens, adapts their approach to what is being said and avoids interpreting what is said to fit in with their own ideas. Interviewing is a skill that must be learned and practised. Although there is no one correct way of conducting an interview, the following guidelines may be of assistance:

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 280
content: Rapport. In order to establish good contact with the interviewee, the interviewer needs to:

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 281
content: Decide the purpose of the interview and what is to be gained from it.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 282
content: Decide the questions to be asked during the interview.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 283
content: Ensure that any information, reports or data required to back-up the interview are readily available.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 284
content: Decide when the interview is to take place. Arrange a convenient time for both interviewer and interviewee so that there is no need to rush the interview.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 285
content: Arrange a suitable location for the interview. Avoid discomfort or distractions. A comfortable room without a telephone is ideal. Telephone interruptions can destroy the relationship built up between the interviewer and interviewee. One of the most irritating distractions is that of people ‘barging in’ during the interview. Prevent this from happening by placing an ‘Interview In Progress - Please Do Not Enter’ notice on the door.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 286
content: A friendly, sympathetic, but emotionally detached relationship should be established to put the respondent at ease. This should gain their confidence and thus persuade them to talk freely and frankly about themselves.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 287
content: Whenever a candidate has to wait in another room before the interview, the interviewer should always escort them into the interview room. In this way contact is made in less formal surroundings than the interview room; the rapport thus established can help to smooth the way into the interview itself.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 288
content: The interviewer(s) should introduce themselves fully.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 289
content: The interviewee should be told the reason for the interview.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 290
content: Difficult or controversial topics at the beginning of an interview should be avoided. Allow the interviewee to get used to talking. This can be achieved by starting with an ‘easy to talk about topic’.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 291
content: Content. The interviewer can elicit facts efficiently only if they ask the right sort of questions and pose them in an appropriate manner. The main points to note are:

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 292
content: Do not read out facts. Repeating information that is already available in forms or publications wastes time and can antagonise the interviewee.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 293
content: Use appropriate language level. The interviewer should make sure the interviewee understands the questions using the most appropriate vocabulary for the interview.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 294
content: Ask one question at a time. Rambling, multiple questions confuse the interviewee and are difficult to answer. Keep questions simple, unambiguous and to the point.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 295
content: Avoid leading questions. Avoid questions that hint at the answer expected; some interviewees will tend to give the answer they think is wanted.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 296
content: Avoid trick questions. Trick questions that attempt to ‘catch out’ the interviewee provide little information and can endanger the contact that has been built up.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 297
content: Use comparative questions. It is easier for an interviewee to say which of two things does the indiviudal find more difficult than it is for the individual to state how difficult something is in absolute terms.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 298
content: Use open questions. The interviewer should try to use questions beginning with words such as “tell me about...”, “how ...”, “when ...”, “why...”, rather than those which demand a simple “yes” or “no” answer.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 299
content: Control. To ensure that the interview flows smoothly from topic to topic and control is retained, the interviewer should attempt to:

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 300
content: Avoid interruptions. Interruptions can cut off the interviewee’s train of thought. The interviewer should interrupt only when necessary in order to avoid digression, or to regain control.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 301
content: Use pauses wisely. Do not rush to fill any pauses that may occur in an interview with another question. Pauses give both interviewer and interviewee a chance to consider what has been said and the interviewee may spontaneously continue with further information.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 302
content: Handle delicate issues carefully. On occasion it may be necessary to ask questions about topics which are emotionally charged or which may cause distress or embarrassment. These topics should be left until effective rapport has been established, introduced when a natural opportunity occurs and discussed in an open, objective, but tactful way.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 303
content: Summarise. It is useful occasionally to summarise what has been covered. This helps ensure that all the relevant points are covered and that the interviewee’s statements have been understood.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 304
content: Be flexible. The main advantage of the interview is its flexibility in that points can be followed up as and when they arise. This advantage will be lost if the interviewer follows a preconceived plan rigidly and without reference to what has been said. The interviewer must:

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 305
content: Be prepared to adapt themselves to the natural flow of the interview.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 306
content: Follow up leads as necessary.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 307
content: Ensure that, in the end, all the information required has been obtained that is needed.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 308
content: Recording Responses. It is impossible to remember everything that was said in an interview. To avoid later distortion, interviewers must try to record responses during the interview, without breaking contact with the interviewer.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 309
content: Beware of bias. The purpose of the interview is to collect information as accurately and objectively as possible. The interviewer should guard against introducing bias by interpreting the replies to fit in with their preconceived ideas. It is also important to avoid biasing the replies by expressing approval/censure. The interviewer must suppress their own opinions and feelings and help the flow of conversation with neutral phrases such as “good”, “I see” or “go on”.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 310
content: Interviewee questions. After answering a series of questions it is reasonable to allow the interviewee to ask some of their own. These should be answered before ending the interview.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 311
content: Thank interviewees. Finally, end the interview on the right note and thank the interviewee for their help and information. Remember that it may be necessary to interview them again at a later date.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 312
content: Interviewing techniques checklist.	The following list is a summary of points to consider when conducting an interview as part of the data gathering process.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 313
content: Contact:

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 314
content: Be prepared: ‘read in and ready’.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 315
content: Ensure a suitable environment.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 316
content: In time and enough time.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 317
content: Introduce yourself (if necessary).

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 318
content: Be pleasant but not too amiable.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 319
content: Make sure the interviewee knows the object of the interview.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 320
content: Reduce tension.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 321
content: Start with an ‘easy to talk about’ topic.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 322
content: Content:

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 323
content: Do not read out facts from forms.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 324
content: Use the appropriate language level and adjust as necessary.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 325
content: Ask one question at a time.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 326
content: Avoid leading questions.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 327
content: Avoid trick questions.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 328
content: Make use of comparative questions.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 329
content: Use indirect open questions.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 330
content: Distinguish between skill and enthusiasm.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 331
content: Explore the reasons for statements.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 332
content: Control:

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 333
content: Avoid interrupting the interviewee.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 334
content: Use pauses widely.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 335
content: Handle delicate issues carefully and as opportunity occurs.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 336
content: Summarise from time to time.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 337
content: Be flexible rather than rigid.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 338
content: Use open, probing then linked questions.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 339
content: Follow leads given by the interviewee.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 340
content: Keep a balance between the points of your plan.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 341
content: Make notes.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 342
content: Beware of bias.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 343
content: Avoid ridicule.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 344
content: Give the interviewee chance to add points at the end.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 345
content: Answer interviewees’ questions and thank them.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 346
content: Recording responses. It is rarely possible to record all that a respondent says during an interview and it would be of little value in any case since all the answers would then appear to be different. What is necessary is the grouping of answers under suitable headings, so that the completed schedule will indicate clearly and concisely what the interviewee may have taken a quarter of an hour to say. It is then appropriate for the interviewer to indicate how the answer has been recorded (e.g. “Am I right in putting you down as saying?”). This gives the respondent time to think again and for the interviewer to check that what has been said has really been understood. If the answer does not fit under an already accepted heading then it must be inserted under a new heading, which will in turn be available for all subsequent interviews. A pocket-dictating machine may be useful but permission must be gained to use one. Recording interviews can also inhibit interviewees.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 347
content: Attempt to transcribe a recording is prohibitive due to the amount of time required. It may be worth considering the use of a second team member to record responses. This will leave the interviewer free to concentrate and develop the interview. A successful interview is dependent upon:

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 348
content: Careful planning.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 349
content: Good questioning technique.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 350
content: Establishing an effective good rapport with the interviewee(s).

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 351
content: Advantages and disadvantages of interviews. Interviews have the advantage of being flexible, allowing subjects not previously considered by the interviewer to be raised and explored. They can be extremely time-consuming, hence they may be used to clarify issues raised from questionnaires for relatively small numbers. A structure must be developed (see Interview Schedule below) to record the strength of opinions given. Interviewers and those analysing the data need to be trained if similar opinions are to be rated by different individuals. Once achieved, information obtained from different interviewers can be compared:

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 352
content: Advantages:

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 353
content: Easier to tailor to the audience. The interviewer can select only those questions that are relevant to a particular situation. This is particularly important when the Role in question is unusual and it would be time- consuming, costly and unacceptably bulky to produce a detailed questionnaire to cover all possibilities.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 354
content: The interview can be conducted with reasonable speed (depending on circumstances).

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 355
content: Wide range of topics can be covered to required depth. Entirely new points of interest can arise. The interviewer can deal with these immediately and add them to the list of questions to be put to all remaining respondents.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 356
content: Personal contact can reinforce commitment to study and raise response rate.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 357
content: The interviewer can check that the respondent has understood technical expressions and terms which have been used in the questionnaire. For example, a term like ‘Defence Writing’ is open to numerous interpretations. To one person it may mean the mechanics of writing, i.e. layout, conventions etc, while to another it concerns matters of style and content.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 358
content: Disadvantages:

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 359
content: Time intensive - not only the interview itself, but the analysis of data it produces.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 360
content: Data may be of complex nature requiring structured/thematic analysis.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 361
content: Requires experienced personnel to conduct the interview.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 362
content: Lack of objectivity, further to which the relationship between interviewer and respondent can become confrontational limiting transmission of objective information.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 363
content: Can be influenced by perception - there may be bias for, as well as against, a particular topic.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 364
content: Observations

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 365
content: Requirements. Observation involves watching, recording and analysing. Observing a particular activity is influenced by the fact that human perception is highly subjective. The fact that an individual is equipped with functioning senses does not make that person a skilled observer. Different people looking at the same design or object will see different things, due in part to their interests, biases and backgrounds.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 366
content: Coding. The observation may be unstructured, with the person who is observing being as open-minded as possible and using his or her judgement about which events are considered important. Alternatively, it may be highly structured by the use of coded schedules that guide attention to specific types of event. The categories that are selected will be those where changes are expected as a result of training, or those that are thought to be particularly important to the success of the Role. Unstructured observations should be avoided. Use pre-determined criteria to increase the reliability and validity of the data collected.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 367
content: Advantages and disadvantages of observations. Observation of procedure is important in the areas of skills training and relates particularly to the areas of speed, sequencing, manual dexterity and safety. As with questionnaires and interviews, to be effective, observations require formal structure in the form of an observation schedule. The advantages and disadvantages of gathering data by observation are highlighted as follows:

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 368
content: Advantages:

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 369
content: Direct experience can be utilised.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 370
content: Real time analysis.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 371
content: Can be done without co-operation of operator.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 372
content: Whole situation of activity is included.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 373
content: Activity is placed in context - aids understanding.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 374
content: Disadvantages:

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 375
content: May lack objectivity - influenced by perception.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 376
content: Potential blizzard of information.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 377
content: May concentrate on unrepresentative individual(s).

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 378
content: False performance - operators aware of being observed.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 379
content: Time intensive.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 380
content: Reports/logs

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 381
content: Training reports. These should cover an ex-trainee’s Role performance and should be completed by the employing officer/line manager. Reports should be structured if they are to be of value. Examples of training reports are:

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 382
content: RN: Form S3018.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 383
content: Army: Training Deficiency Reports.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 384
content: RAF: Training Improvement Form (TIF).

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 385
content: Open-ended reports. Open-ended report forms may be administratively feasible, but may suffer from lack of relevance, as the type of comment(s) required may not be clear to a reporting officer. In addition to which they may lack comprehensiveness, due to limitations of space and time. They are usually fragmentary and often misguided. Report forms using rating scales are designed to direct the reporting officer’s attention to specific behaviours. This enables reports of different supervisors to be accurately quantified. The main disadvantage of this method is the restriction it places on reporting officers’ freedom of expression, although this can be mitigated by provision of room for open-ended comments.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 386
content: Equipment reports. These can be used to identify equipment malfunctions which may have training implications.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 387
content: Post Exercise Reports (PXRs). These can be used to highlight the application of skills acquired during training in a realistic environment

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 388
content: Work records. A study of the tasks carried out can give a reasonably accurate picture of the performance and the standards involved in a Role. Additional records containing details of time taken, lack of skills, incidence of accidents etc can sometimes complement these, which can be pointers towards areas of training deficiency.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 389
content: Log books. The log book can be a valuable source of information. Its main value lies in that it allows a direct comparison to be made between what the ex-trainee is able to do as a result of training and what they are required to do when employed on an operational task.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 390
content: Analysing Collected Data

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 391
content: Quantitative and qualitative data analysis. Quantitative data by their very nature lend themselves to statistical analysis. However, with qualitative data there may be trends (patterns, themes) present, which could go unnoticed. One of the problems of dealing with qualitative data is the ‘blizzard of information’ that can be reproduced. This can often be unstructured in content and resource intensive in terms of workforce and time to analyse. Such considerations need to be included during initial project management planning. In analysing qualitative data the quality of the analyst must be taken into consideration, as unlike quantitative data analysis where the issues are more readily identifiable, qualitative analysis requires greater degree(s) of interpretation. Analysts must be conscious of the possibility of knee jerk reactions when confronting data for the first time

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 392
content: Qualitative data allow a vast amount of (potentially wide-ranging) information to be considered, allowing the respondent to provide depth of feeling over complex issues which may be difficult to elicit by purely quantitative terms alone. That said, in order to obtain a full picture, qualitative data should not be treated in isolation, but should be compared with quantitative data.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 393
content: Triangulation of data. Triangulation is the combination of different data gathering techniques to investigate the same issue and will usually combine both quantitative and qualitative data methods. For example, rather than simply completing a questionnaire in respect of how an individual performs a task, they might also be interviewed and observed conducting the task. The use of questionnaires together with observation, or qualitative with quantitative data gathering techniques, for example, can reduce the chance of distorting the results or introducing bias within the methodology. To that end triangulation allows greater confidence in the research results regardless of the data gathering methodologies applied.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 394
content: Information sources. Collecting data can be gained from a number of different points of view: the Role holders (ex-trainees), the Role holders’ supervisors/line managers and the participant observer. The Role holders can reflect on the adequacy of the training they received; the line managers can comment on their performance when carrying out their Role. The observer can collect first-hand data of the Role holders conducting the Role tasks. Comparing these sources of information enables a more accurate and unbiased method of data gathering.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 395
content: Data combination. The combination of different data gathering techniques to investigate a particular issue usually is a combination of both qualitative and quantitative methods:

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 396
content: Triangulation of analysts. This uses 3 or more analysts to look at the same set of data independently. If similar findings come from all analysts then it is likely that objectivity is being applied.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 397
content: Triangulation of data. This involves 3 or more types or sets of data and subject them to the same analytical procedures. For example, if interview notes, questionnaire responses and observation notes produce similar findings it is likely that the analytical process is being applied objectively.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 398
content: Triangulation of target population. This concerns 3 or more types of target population. For example, the ex-trainees, their immediate line managers/supervisors, commanding officers and trainers. If similar findings are produced it is highly likely that an objective picture has been achieved.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 399
content: Data Coding

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 400
content: Requirement. Some form of coding (grouping, classification) is required before analysis can begin identifying themes:

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 401
content: All information needs to be read thoroughly to obtain a clear picture of the main issues.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 402
content: Themes/patterns/trends need to be identified and clearly highlighted.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 403
content: Repeated instances of these themes need to be recorded in the form of ‘tallys’.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 404
content: These ‘tallys’ can then be recorded as numerical responses allowing follow-on statistical analysis to take place.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 405
content: Document Information

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 406
content: Document Coverage

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 407
content: This DTSM supersedes all previous DTSMs on Governance of Individual Training The totality of DTSMs included in the DTSMs Suite, of which this document is a part, are listed on the DTSMs SharePoint site.

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 408
content: Document Information

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 409
content: Document Editions / Versions

document: DTSM 5 Evaluation of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0
heading: Section 410
content: Annual editions of this DTSM will be published every December in time for upcoming year relevant to the DTSM. Throughout the year, different versions of the current edition may also be published. When every new edition is published, the versions will reset to 1.
